data.text: Contents
Introduction
The Trust's priority for pest control is to prevent them from gaining access to premises and/or finding suitable habitats within buildings.

Premises shall be designed, constructed, kept clean and maintained in Terminal Cleans good repair and condition, as to avoid the risk of harbouring pests, contaminating foodstuffs, equipment, furnishing and fixtures.
Effective pest control necessitates rapid identification of the species causing concern, a knowledge of its lifecycle and the most economical, rapid and safe way of eliminating it.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Reduce the risk of pests that can carry infectious organisms that may transfer from insects and animals to humans and therefore cause a risk to patients, staff or visitors
To prevent the ingress of pests into clinical and non-clinical areas
To ensure all staff are aware of their responsibilities for pest control
To ensure that the Trust has approved pest control contractors relevant
Definitions

table_items.text: The presence of rats, mice, insects or mites in numbers or under conditions which involve an immediate or potential risk of contamination, loss or damage to food, clinical equipment or activities.
Any living creature capable of directly or indirectly contaminating food or clinical equipment, fixtures and surfaces.
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Health and Committee – To ensure that this procedure is regularly reviewed, update where necessary.
To address any shortfall highlighted in the internal audit and review process
Chief Executive - Has overall responsibility for the safety of Trust employees including contractor staff and will delegate such responsibilities to the management team.

Chief Estates & Facilities Officer - The Estates & Facilities Chief Officer is the executive director lead for the management of risk for pest control and is responsible for ensuring hospital premises are suitable for healthcare, they are well maintained, clean and pest free.
This will be done by ensuring the following actions:
Ensuring that the Trust complies with all relevant legislation with respect to pest control and any other appropriate regulations
Ensuring that all the Trust premises have active pest control measures in place
Appointing trained and competent managers to oversee pest control
Ensuring that suitable and sufficient resources are made available so that specialist service contractors may be engages
As far as is practicably possible, all buildings and utilities will be designed, constructed and maintained to prevent ingress and harbourage of pests
EFM Maintenance Management Lead (or nominated deputy) for Pest control responsible for:
Conduct regular contract reviews with incumbent supplier of pest control services.

Receiving and acting upon contractors written reports and to note the action taken to combat pest infestation since the contractor's last report, including any works required by the Trust to eliminate harbourage and improve hygiene.
Effective assessment and action relating to proposals for further action by the contractor.
Coordinating investigations into incidents, pest evidence or sightings of pests and making recommendations.
Overall co-ordination and monitoring of Pest Control contractors.
Keeping up to date with legislation and guidance, relating to Pest control and Environmental Health and implementing changes to the Policy as necessary.
For receipt, investigation and initiating appropriate action on all reports on pest evidence or sightings of pests.
For forming the main link between the Trust and the contractor in response of pest control issues.
Implementation of pest awareness within the Trust, calling on advice from specialist sources when necessary.
Completion of incidents on the Ulysses system as appropriate.
Assessing requirements for and ensuring availability of Personal Protective Equipment.

Ensuring records are maintained showing the date the infestation and the action taken and submit a quarterly report assuring compliance with the Key Performance Indicators to The Infection Prevention Committee.
Ensure all Health and Safety documentation and permits to work are in place.
Ensure evidence of competent persons who have been trained is held on file.

Infection Prevention and Control Team - The Infection Prevention and Control Team will work in conjunction with the Maintenance Management Lead to ensure compliance with national standards, legislation and in the event of a pest control issue affecting clinical services.
All employees Responsible for:
Maintaining standards including good housekeeping by their own actions in accordance with this policy.
Reporting issues regarding pest control, cleaning and maintenance to the Estates Help Desk.
Completion of incidents on the Ulysses/ Datix system.
Adhering to procedures and guidance within the policy for good housekeeping, correct storage and reporting.
Pest Control Contractors

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust will ensure an appropriate pest control contract is in operation at all times. The pest control contract will be monitored by the Estates department against (a pest control) contract specification.
The Pest Control Service shall provide, manage and operate a comprehensive system of pest control management using personnel who are fully trained, qualified
and able to provide high quality professional and practical advice. Two planned preventative site assessments are to be made at night, one in the winter months and one in the summer months.

The Contractor will perform the contract in accordance with the Codes of Practice of the British Pest Control Association (BPCA) all affecting legislation, local government guidelines and Trust policy and procedures.
Any service provided by the contractor shall be carried out in an appropriate manner to the entire satisfaction of the Trust.

Contractors will be required to carry out routine inspections at the locations and frequency agreed with the nominated manager. They will be required to agree the exact date and time of each inspection with the nominated manager. On each inspection visit, the contractor will be required to check all insect monitor stations and all rodent bait stations together with a general inspection of high risk areas, for signs of any pest activity.
The contractor shall provide written report of every visit whether emergency or otherwise.
The report shall detail:
The date and time of the visit
The type of visit i.e. routine, emergency, follow up or job work
The locations inspected and/or treated

Any evidence of infestation including both the scientific name and general term for the pest. This applied to scheduled and non-scheduled pests the type of treatment carried out including the common name of the pesticide and the amount used.
Any proofing, housekeeping or hygiene recommendations to eliminate causes of infestation.
Any precautions necessary to be observed by Trust staff as a result of action taken by the contractor.
A list of monitors and their locations.
Technician's signature.
Nominated Estates & Facilities Manager's signature.

The contractors' written report will also detail the pesticides applied together with any warnings or precautions to be undertaken by Trust staff in relation to the pesticides applied or work carried out.
It should be noted that an important aspect of pest control is denial of access to pests and that the maintenance of an environment is important as it discourages the development of infestation.

The contractor shall notify the nominated Estates & Facilities manager in writing of the state of infestation of the locations at the expiration of “Riddance times” specified and any condition observed by him which may be conducive to infestations by pests or which may hinder efforts to combat them within 10 working days of such observation.
All adverse incidents must be reported on the Ulysses/ Datix system.
Individual Pests
Houseflies
6.1.1 Significance

6.1.2 Houseflies can transmit intestinal worms or their eggs and are potential vectors of disease such as food poisoning and gastro-enteritis. They will frequent and feed indiscriminately on any liquefiable solid food, putrefying material or food stores for human consumption.
Control
6.2.1  Flies have rapid, prolific breeding habits and high mobility. In order to break the life- cycle, control measures should be directed against larval and adult flies.
Hygiene/Management

6.3.1  Satisfactory hygiene is necessary to limit potential breeding sites and food sources. Entry of flies into buildings can be prevented by 1.12mm mesh fly scree, air curtains, bead screens or self-closing door equipment with rubber seals.
Cockroaches
6.4.1 Distribution

6.4.2 Cockroaches are common in premises associated with the production or handling of food. Gregarious and nocturnal they spend the day hiding in cracks and crevices around areas such as sinks, drains, cookers, the backs of cupboards and in refrigerator motor compartments. They favour buildings with service ducts and complex plumbing installations which allow them to travel freely.
Significance

6.5.1  Cockroaches are potential vectors of diseases such as food poisoning and gastroenteritis can spread antibiotic resistant bacteria of many types. Their diet is omnivorous and includes fermenting substances, soiled dressings, hair, parchment, wallpaper, faeces and food for human consumption.
Control

6.6.1  Monitoring and control is essential although successful control of cockroaches is a complex subject and depends very much upon tailoring control measures to the species concern. Infestations can be difficult to control as cockroach eggs are poorly penetrated by insecticides. Consequently surveillance of the area by the pest control contractor may need to be prolonged.
Hygiene/Management
6.7.1  A high standard of hygiene will deny sources of food and hiding places.
Ants
Black Ants:

6.9.1  Foraging worker ants cause a nuisance as they travel widely in search of food, following well-defined trails and clustering around the food source. Sweet foods are preferred.  They  are obviously an  unpleasant  sight  and  may  damage  food for human consumption.
Pharaoh's Ants:

6.10.1 These 2mm omnivorous light brown ants are half the size of black ants. They cannot breed without artificial heat, are very persistent and pose a serious cross infection risk in hospitals. The ants may be found in wall cavities, heating pipes, behind sinks and ovens and therefore in laundry, linen rooms, clinical and residential areas. They are particularly attracted to sweet or light protein.
Hygiene/Management

6.11.1 Although frequently inaccessible and difficult to destroy, ant's nests must be eradicated. If infestation is to be successfully controlled hormone treatment is required which sterilises the female ant.
Wasps

6.12.1 Wasp stings cause pain and distress. Some individuals are particularly sensitive. Wasp nests are only used for one season, so it may be possible to put up with the problem temporarily. They are often found in cavities in brickwork, in air bricks and roof vents. The nest can be treated by the Trust's pest control contractor; such work may be best carried out in the evening or weekend as poisoned stupefied wasps can cause problems. Particular attention should be paid to areas around rubbish bins that should be kept in a hygienic condition.
Other Insect Pests

6.13.1 There are many other insect pests that occur sporadically in hospitals. The most common of these being flies of various species, crickets, silverfish and the stored product insects and mites who can be found infesting dried foods such as flour weevils.
Mice and Rats

6.14.1 The Trust will take reasonable steps to ensure that its buildings are rodent proofed by, for example, fitting collars where pipes pass through walls and by filling gaps in the building fabric etc. All food and organic waste shall be kept in rodent proof containers.
Bats

6.15.1 Bats are protected by the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 and the Conservation (Natural Habitats etc.) Regulations  (amended 2007). The penalties for contravention are severe. If bats are discovered in any of the Trust's buildings or on any of its land they must not under any circumstances be killed, expelled, stopped from gaining access, touched or disturbed. Contractors must be prevented from doing work anywhere near them. English Nature should be contacted for advice.
Birds

6.16.1 The nuisance of birds can be controlled in the first instance by preventative measures e.g. blocking of nesting holes and the application of devices to discourage perching. Netting and trapping can also be considered with the aim of immediate release away from the area/location of capture. As a last resort birds may be culled by shooting with the approval of the Trust Chief Executive and local police authority. No attempt should be made to poison them. Whichever method is employed it should take into account whether the birds are currently in a nesting season or whether they are protected by law. Advice should be sought from the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB).
Squirrels

6.17.1 Can cause damage in roof spaces via chewing to; woodwork, ceilings and insulation on electrical wiring, or damage to loft insulation for nesting. The best method of control is to proof the building/loft. Prevention is better than cure. If a cure is required the best form of control is trapping with the use of a humane squirrel trap.
Foxes

6.18.1 Urban foxes may occasionally spread disease such as toxocora and leptospirosis and Rabies. Humane removal or culling may be utilised, however, these measures are unlikely to provide a long-term solution, species populace their readiness to move into vacant territories.
Reporting
All sightings of pests or evidence of their existence should be reported in the first to the Estates and Facilities Help Desk immediately.
The information required will include:
The location i.e. ward, department, clinic etc.
Precise locations i.e. ward bay. Bathroom. Clinical room, office, by room number.
Possible scale and frequency of pest sightings.
The name of the person reporting the date and time of the sighting.
Isolated sittings/signs of pests such as hairs, droppings, gnawing, damage must be taken seriously and action taken immediately.
Training Requirements
No specific training requirements.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the EFM Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and procedures. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the EFM Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
